title: US soya bean farmers battered by trade dispute with China
summary: Farms face falling prices and lost income amid the escalating US-China trade war.

title: The politics of celebration: Captives vs prisoners
summary: We compare and contrast how Israelis celebrate captive releases, while Palestinians are ordered not to.

title: Afghan foreign minister in India: Why New Delhi is embracing Taliban now
summary: India never aligned with the Taliban, but regional geopolitical realignment is forcing revamp of ties, say analysts.

title: Cameroon’s Issa Tchiroma Bakary claims presidential election victory
summary: Opposition candidate unilaterally declares himself victor, and calls on incumbent 92-year-old Paul Biya to concede.

title: KL Rahul, India defeat West Indies in second Test to sweep series
summary: India wins the two-match series with a dominant seven-wicket victory in New Delhi before their tour of Australia.

title: Death toll from devastating Mexico flooding rises
summary: The death toll from last week’s torrential rains in Mexico has risen to 64 as authorities expand the search.

title: Venezuela to close Norway embassy after opposition leader wins Nobel Prize
summary: The news comes just days after Maria Corina Machado was announced the winner of the 2025 Nobel Peace Prize in Oslo.

title: Why is India prosecuting Muslims who said ‘I love Muhammad’?
summary: More than 2,500 people have been charged as an initial crackdown on the expression has spawned broader protests.

title: US news outlets say they will not agree to Pentagon reporting restrictions
summary: Reporters must promise not to publish unauthorised material to obtain press credentials.

title: Cape Verde clinches historic first qualification for FIFA World Cup
summary: The island nation, located off the African coast, becomes the second-smallest country to qualify for the World Cup.

title: LIVE: Released Palestinians in Gaza allege hunger, abuse in Israeli jails
summary: Deal comes as families in Israel and Palestine reunite with loved ones freed from captivity in Gaza and Israeli jails.

title: Joint Egypt-Qatar-Turkiye-US statement on Gaza: The full text
summary: Trump-backed proclamation backing Gaza ceasefire stresses equality, but stops short of supporting Palestine statehood.

title: En direct : Israël attend les corps d'otages morts à Gaza
summary: Donald Trump a proclamé lundi un "jour formidable pour le Moyen-Orient" lors d'un sommet sur Gaza en Égypte. La première phase du plan américain prévoit, outre le cessez-le-feu et un retrait israélien de certains secteurs de Gaza, le retour dans les 72 heures des 47 derniers otages retenus à Gaza, dont 27 sont morts. L'armée israélienne a annoncé la remise de seulement quatre corps d'otages via le CICR lundi. Suivez la situation en direct.

title: Gaza : Israël a-t-il laissé des poupées et des conserves piégées à l'explosif dans l'enclave ?
summary: Alors que des centaines de milliers de déplacés Palestiniens profitent du cessez-le-feu pour remonter vers le Nord de l'enclave, de fausses informations prolifèrent sur les réseaux sociaux. Selon un tweet viral, Israël aurait placé des explosifs dans des poupées et des conserves de nourriture. En réalité, le jouet en question est visible dans une vidéo de 2018 au Yémen et les prétendues conserves alimentaires sont des emballages d'allumeurs de mine antichar.

title: Otages libérés, cessez-le-feu à Gaza... La fin d'une "ère de terreur" ?
summary: En cette journée qualifiée d'historique, les 20 derniers otages israéliens vivants détenus à Gaza par le Hamas ont été libérés ce lundi matin et ont retrouvé leurs familles en Israël. Cette libération a été négociée contre celle de près de 2000 prisonniers palestiniens arrivés à Gaza ou en Cisjordanie. À Charm el-Cheikh en Égypte, une vingtaine de pays se sont réunis en présence de Donald Trump : les pays arabes mais aussi la Turquie et plusieurs pays européens dont la France et le Royaume-Uni. Benjamin Netanyahu a quant à lui décliné l'invitation du président américain, qui s'est exprimé devant la Knesset plus tôt dans la journée en évoquant un "nouvel âge d'or au Moyen-Orient". La phase I du plan Trump est elle achevée ? Est-ce la fin d'une "ère de terreur" à Gaza ?

title: Non, le chef de l’Unrwa n’a pas déclaré qu’il n’y avait pas de famine à Gaza
summary: Selon les autorités israéliennes, le directeur de l’UNRWA, Philippe Lazzarini, aurait admis qu’il n’y avait pas de famine à Gaza : l’enclave disposerait d’assez de nourriture pour nourrir sa population pendant trois mois. Il s’agit de propos tronqués : le chef de l’UNRWA parlait de stocks situés à l’extérieur de Gaza.

title: "Âge d'or" du Moyen-Orient, fin d'un "long cauchemar"... extraits du discours de Trump à la Knesset
summary: Devant la Knesset, Donald Trump a salué lundi un "triomphe incroyable pour Israël et le monde" après le cessez-le-feu à Gaza, prédisant le début d'un "âge d'or pour Israël et le Moyen-Orient". Un discours fleuve au cours duquel il a également évoqué la perspective d'une paix avec l'Iran et appelé de ses vœux une amnistie pour le Premier ministre israélien Benjamin Netanyahu, poursuivi pour corruption.

title: Guerre à Gaza : "Trump a dit ça suffit", dit Robert Malley, ancien conseiller de Biden
summary: Dans un entretien accordé à France 24, Robert Malley, diplomate américain en charge du Moyen-Orient sous Clinton, Obama et Biden, reconnaît que Donald Trump "a accompli" ce que "son prédécesseur n'était pas capable" d’accomplir. "Le président Trump a "mis le poing sur la table" en disant aux parties "ça suffit, on arrête cette guerre" à Gaza, explique-t-il.

title: Cessez-le-feu à Gaza : "Une lueur d'espoir ?"
summary: A la Une de la presse, ce lundi 13 octobre, l’entrée en vigueur, ce matin, de l’accord conclu entre Israël et le Hamas, sous la houlette de Donald Trump.

title: Les derniers otages vivants de retour en Israël, Ramallah accueille des cars de Palestiniens libérés
summary: Le Hamas a libéré lundi les derniers otages israéliens encore en vie retenus dans la bande de Gaza. Une foule en liesse et en pleurs a accueilli à Ramallah l'arrivée de cars transportant des Palestiniens tout juste relâchés par les autorités israéliennes.

title: Les otages seront libérés tôt lundi matin, forte émotion à Tel-Aviv
summary: Sur la place des "Otages" à Tel-Aviv, la foule est nombreuse, dans l'attente de la libération des otages. Les Israéliens sont émus, une page va se tourner, et ils ne comptent pas aller se coucher, raconte l'envoyée spéciale de France 24, Pauline Godart. La libération des 20 otages vivants retenus à Gaza devrait avoir lieu tôt lundi. Une autre personne est vivement attendue : le président américain Donald Trump.

title: Sommet de Charm el-Cheikh : Trump célèbre "un jour formidable pour le Moyen-Orient"
summary: Depuis Charm el-Cheikh, en Égypte, où s'est tenu un sommet sur Gaza, Donald Trump a salué "un jour formidable pour le Moyen-Orient". Le Hamas a libéré lundi matin les derniers otages israéliens encore en vie retenus dans l'enclave palestinienne, tandis qu'à Ramallah, la joie a éclaté à l'arrivée des prisonniers palestiniens libérés par Israël. Retrouvez le fil de la journée du 13 octobre.

title: Alain Dieckhoff : "La responsabilité de Netanyahu au sujet du 7-Octobre va être posée par les urnes"
summary: Un accord a donc été trouvé entre Israël et le Hamas sous l'égide de Donald Trump. Il prévoit la libération en une seule fois des 48 derniers otages, qu'ils soient vivants ou morts. Cette libération devrait intervenir dans les prochaines heures, lundi matin au plus tard, en échange de près de 2000 prisonniers palestiniens. Le cessez-le-feu est pour l'heure respecté, l'armée israélienne s'est retirée de certains secteurs de la bande de Gaza permettant à quelques 500 000 Gazaouis de retourner vers le nord pour retrouver leurs habitations. Quel avenir à présent pour les Gazaouis ? Nous en parlons dans "Au cœur de l’info" avec Alain Dieckhoff, sociologue, chercheur au CNRS et ancien directeur du CERI de Sciences Po.

title: L'aide humanitaire arrive progressivement à Gaza
summary: Plusieurs camions d'aide humanitaire ont été aperçus, arrivant ce matin au poste-frontière de Rafah, au sud de Gaza, à la frontière avec l'Égypte, suite au cessez-le-feu entré en vigueur il y a à peu près 48 heures. On analyse la situation dans la Bande de Gaza avec Rami Abou Jamous, journaliste indépendant dans la Bande de Gaza.

title: En Chine, la répression s’abat sur l’une des principales Eglises « souterraines » du pays
summary: Le pasteur Jin Mingri, fondateur de l’Eglise de Sion, non reconnue par le gouvernement chinois, et au moins 20 autres ecclésiastiques de son mouvement ont été placés en détention.

title: Incursion de drones russes : « L’OTAN a une nouvelle ambition : passer de la logique de police du ciel à celle de défense aérienne »
summary: La chercheuse Amélie Zima expose, dans une tribune au « Monde », les solutions dont dispose l’Alliance atlantique face à la violation de l’espace aérien européen par des engins russes, afin d’adopter une réponse ferme face à la Russie, sans pour autant entraîner d’escalade.

title: Immigration : l’accord franco-britannique sur le renvoi de migrants contesté en justice
summary: Seize organisations ont demandé la suspension de l’accord « One in, one out », qui prévoit un échange de migrants entre Paris et Londres pour dissuader les tentatives de traversée de la Manche.

title: EN DIRECT, Gaza : l’Iran considère que l’appel à la paix de Donald Trump est « en contradiction » avec les actes des Etats-Unis
summary: Téhéran « considère que la volonté de dialogue exprimée par le président américain est en contradiction avec le comportement hostile et criminel des Etats-Unis », faisant référence à la guerre de douze jours en juin, menée par Israël avec le soutien de Washington.

title: Donald Trump et la guerre à Gaza : huit mois de recalibrage et le succès d’une approche hors norme de la diplomatie
summary: Le président américain a savouré son triomphe après un échange d’otages et de détenus entre Israël et le Hamas. Sans lever toutes les zones d’ombre autour d’un plan de paix imposé au forceps.

title: EN DIRECT, guerre en Ukraine : Donald Trump confirme qu’il va recevoir Volodymyr Zelensky à la Maison Blanche vendredi
summary: Les deux chefs d’Etat se sont entretenus à deux reprises ce week-end, alors que plusieurs dirigeants, dont le chancelier allemand, Friedrich Merz, pressent le président américain de « mettre fin » au conflit en Ukraine.

title: Donald Trump promet « espoir, harmonie, opportunité » au Moyen-Orient sous les ovations de la Knesset
summary: Le président américain a été ovationné, lundi, par le Parlement israélien, après la libération des 20 derniers otages encore vivants. S’il a salué le premier ministre, Benyamin Nétanyahou, un « homme au courage exceptionnel », il a également souligné la difficulté qu’il a eue à le faire sortir de sa stratégie meurtrière.

title: « Les agents IA sont en passe d’être considérés comme des travailleurs à part entière »
summary: L’idiot regarde le doigt quand on lui montre la lune, mais Donald Trump a, lui, bien compris que l’intelligence artificielle va doper l’économie américaine sous son second mandat, explique, dans sa chronique, Arnaud Leparmentier, journaliste au « Monde ».

title: Protéger les mineurs et empêcher les contenus autodestructeurs : comment la Californie compte réguler l’IA
summary: La législation signée lundi par le gouverneur démocrate, Gavin Newsom, oblige les plateformes à rappeler aux utilisateurs qu’ils interagissent avec un chatbot et non avec un humain et à orienter les utilisateurs vers des services d’urgence en cas d’idées suicidaires.

title: Rafael Lopez Aliaga, le maire d’extrême droite de Lima, candidat à diriger le Pérou après la destitution de la présidente
summary: Il s’agira de la deuxième fois que M. Lopez Aliaga, se présentera à la présidentielle. Il est porté dans les sondages par son discours de fermeté et ses mesures radicales contre le crime organisé.

title: Ces téléphones volés dans les rues de Londres qui atterrissent à Hongkong
summary: Les vols à la tire de téléphones, la plupart commis par des hommes à vélo électrique, ont explosé dans la capitale britannique. Plusieurs dizaines de personnes ont été arrêtées après une enquête de près d’un an qui a mené jusqu’en Chine.

title: En RDC, une nouvelle attaque des Forces démocratiques alliées fait au moins 19 morts
summary: Dans l’est de République démocratique du Congo, le village de Mukondo a été la cible de l’ADF, un groupe affilié à l’Etat islamique. Un massacre qui souligne l’impuissance des autorités à protéger la population du Nord-Kivu et de l’Ituri.

title: 'Peace deal' or not, Gaza remains the holocaust of our time
summary:
'Peace deal' or not, Gaza remains the holocaust of our time

Submitted by Niamh Ni Bhriain on Tue, 10/07/2025 - 08:44
Two years into Israel's war of extermination, there can be no peace without accountability for the industrial-scale killing or justice for Palestinians who continue to count their dead
Protesters march in a 'red line' demonstration, demanding the Dutch government take a stronger stance against Israel's actions in Gaza, in Amsterdam, the Netherlands, on 5 October 2025 (Richard Wareham/Reuters)
On

Abdullah Ahmed Jihad al-Hasani, a baby boy, not yet one year old. Masah Mohammad Hamza al-Rifi, a baby girl, not yet one year old. Celine Ahmed Mufid al-Yaziji, a baby girl, not yet one year old... a baby... not yet one year old. 

Somebody's whole world, gone in an instant.

In Amsterdam, as the first winds of autumn swept through the city, the names of 69,000 people killed in Israel's genocidal war on Gaza were read aloud, one after the next, day and night without pause, for five full days.

It is a staggering death toll, yet one that is vastly incomplete and already outdated by the time the final name was read.

Applying the calculation used by the Lancet medical journal in a 2024 article, a more accurate figure may be as high as half a million people, but it is likely higher. This would mean that the Israeli-US-European axis of genocide has killed about a quarter of Gaza's 2.3 million inhabitants.

This is the holocaust of our time.

Ghosts of Gaza

Overnight, as I wrote this, Israel destroyed 17 homes, residential buildings and a mosque. By the time it is published, those trapped beneath the rubble have likely suffocated in a cloud of dust, succumbed to death from dehydration, or are slowly wasting away, willing death to come soon to release them from their agony.

Someday, the skeletal remains of the many thousands who died alone in the crevasses of collapsed buildings, wedged between immovable blocks of cement, may eventually be recovered.

If Israel continues to be granted impunity, the dead will be disappeared forever, erased from history along with their homeland

It is far more likely, though, if Israel continues to be granted impunity for its crimes, that they will be disappeared forever. Their bones will be crushed into Palestine's blood-soaked earth or dumped in the Mediterranean Sea, leaving only their ghosts to seek revenge on the Zionist settlers who stole their homeland and occupied it.

The deaths of those whose bodies were obliterated beyond recognition have also not been recorded. Craters hollowed out by US bunker-buster bombs, dropped by US and European-manufactured fighter jets, have turned densely populated areas, once teeming with life, into mass graves of unidentified broken body parts.

Attacks on civil defence teams mean that many bodies, though identifiable when killed, are not recovered. These rotting corpses decay in the midday sun, scavenged by animals devouring limbs, organs and eyeballs, until nothing but bones, licked clean of their flesh, remain.

Gaza is hell on earth.

The list of Gaza's known dead includes entire families - adults followed by teenagers, children and babies. All with matching surnames.

All gone.

Did anyone survive? Is there anyone left who remembers these families? Who will say their names aloud in their homeland? Will they only be read from afar by people who never knew them, but whose hearts break because they are gone?

Follow Middle East Eye's live coverage of Israel's genocide in Gaza

This is a war of extermination, and our governments are accomplices to it. For centuries, European colonial powers wiped out entire peoples. What is happening in Gaza is no different.

But what makes it so deeply disturbing is that it is not occurring out of sight, and we are not learning about it after the fact. No, Palestinians are documenting their own erasure in real time, and we are watching it live.

The political and corporate establishment has made a calculated decision, driven by western powers but with the complicity or tolerance of many Arab states, that the Palestinian people will be sacrificed in order to uphold an imperialist, white, Euro-colonialist world order.

A war remembered

As we recited name after name from a tent in the Netherlands, we wondered whether the people who bore these names in life were burnt alive in similar tents in al-Mawasi.

After two years of genocide in Gaza, will I ever be the same?
Read More »

Images of smoking bodies were broadcast around the world as viewers watched in horror, though we were spared the unbearable stench of burning flesh, until these lives, like the flames that engulfed them, were eventually extinguished.

Were the 45 people burned alive in an Israeli air strike on Rafah among the names read aloud? Or were their smouldering remains too charred to be identified? Rafah was a red line. Now it is gone.

As names poured off the stacks of pages amassed on the podium, it was impossible not to wonder whose name matched which killing, as death bore down on death and Israel savagely destroyed all traces of Palestinian life from Gaza.

As I read the names, one image played over in my mind - a video of a bomb blast, the impact so fierce, so ferocious, that two people were catapulted hundreds of feet into the air.

Sometime last winter, I fixated on this 16-second video, unable to watch it through to the end but equally unable to stop trying. The video sequence was of a rooftop, a thunderous bang, a plume of smoke, bone-chilling screams and two bodies blown to the heavens before falling back to earth.

At what exact moment did they die? Was it when they were hurled upwards? Maybe it was when they landed? Did I read out their names? Who were they in life? Am I betraying their legacy by only recalling them in death?

Other videos too - images of screaming children, of a father's severed head being carried by a wailing child desperately willing him back to life. Did I read out his name? Did the child survive? So tormented were his screams, would it be better if he did not?

What about the doctors picked off one by one as Israeli snipers lined up and took aim as though playing a video game? What about the hospitals blasted by Israeli tanks until no functioning health-care facility remained?

The lack of accountability for such blatant war crimes sends a chilling message that it is not only the Palestinians but also international law that will be erased in Gaza.

In November 2023, as al-Shifa Hospital came under siege, roughly 15km away, European leaders posed for photo-ops in Kibbutz Be'eri, accompanied by those giving the orders for Gaza's destruction.

Images would later emerge of mass graves containing hundreds of bodies crushed under the weight of bulldozers, atrocities that likely occurred as European leaders were being wined and dined by the perpetrators only a short distance away, though a world apart.

Weeks later, newborn babies, who scarcely knew the tenderness of human touch, would die alone in incubators as hospitals were forcibly evacuated and the fuel that powered them ran out.

No justice, no peace

Listed among Gaza's dead was Saeed Darwish al-Kilanei, an 84-year-old man born in a land that was free, a Palestine that existed long before the Zionist entity colonised it.

Surely the only solution is an immediate end to the genocide and ultimately the total dismantling of the Zionist colony

Did Saeed walk the fertile lands of Beit Lahia or Beit Hanoun as a child, harvesting olives in late autumn and feasting on hummus and flat bread? Did he fish in the abundant waters of the Mediterranean and fill his belly by its shores as the sun set? Did he dance dabka and fall in love under a night sky lit not by bombs and drone fire, but by the light of a thousand stars?

In his final years, Saeed witnessed more than 85,000 tonnes of bombs dropped on his homeland - surpassing the tonnage used in World War Two - before he and other elders who were born in a free Palestine and survived the 1948 Nakba were finally killed by the Zionist regime.

What would they say of the regurgitation of the already failed "two-state solution" at the UN General Assembly, or of President Trump's "peace plan" that excludes Palestinians from Gaza, or of states recognising Palestinian statehood while continuing to arm and back the entity that is erasing it?

These so-called "solutions" are so far removed from what is needed that by the time we get to where we need to be, there will be no Palestinians left in Palestine.

Surely the only solution is an immediate end to the genocide, justice for those who survived it and ultimately the total dismantling of the Zionist colony, with the expulsion of settlers from lands they stole back to Europe, the US and elsewhere.

For the media establishment, which normalised and ignored the daily massacres of Palestinians, it essentially already has. In the wake of Trump's "peace plan", renewed media attention has focused on the release of Israeli captives and not the ongoing famine or the myriad ways that Palestinians will continue to die as a result of Israel's genocide, even if the bombs have stopped for now.

Meanwhile, for many politicians, Gaza is an irritation and starving Palestinians an eyesore. When will Israel "finish the job" so they can get on with attending gala dinners and banquets without the inconvenience of Palestine activists showing up and reminding them of their complicity in genocide?

I left Gaza with guilt, sorrow and tears for the son Israel took from me
Read More »

Entirely absent from the "peace plan" is any notion of justice or accountability for the industrial-scale killing, which is hardly surprising considering the plan was drawn up by those who carried it out.

Without justice, there will be no peace.

Palestinian poet Mahmoud Darwish wrote: "We - who are capable of remembrance - are capable of liberation." 

So, despite the futility, the rage and the despair of knowing that, like so many actions over the past two years, remembering Gaza's dead as more continue to be slaughtered will not stop the holocaust nor bring justice for it, we persist in the hope that someday the cumulative effect of our collective efforts just might.

It has to. For as long as Palestinians get up each morning and face the unimaginable each day in Gaza, we have a duty to ensure that this story does not end with their erasure, but with their liberation.

The views expressed in this article belong to the author and do not necessarily reflect the editorial policy of Middle East Eye.

Israel's genocide in Gaza

title: Israeli forces shoot, arrest Palestinians in occupied West Bank
summary:
Israeli forces shoot, arrest Palestinians in occupied West Bank

At least two people were wounded when Israeli troops opened fire on Palestinians while carrying out overnight raids in several areas in the occupied West Bank, says Wafa news agency.

In the town of Anabta, located in Tulkarem, Israeli soldiers shot a young man in the hand, and arrested a number of other youngsters after assaulting them.

In another incident reported in the town of al-Issawiya, near occupied Jerusalem, another young man was injured by Israeli forces before arresting him.

The cities of Qalqilya and Tubas and the town of Tammun have also been stormed by Israeli soldiers, who raided several homes in these areas.

title: Trump says his peace plan is about ‘rebuilding Gaza’
summary:
Trump says his peace plan is about ‘rebuilding Gaza’

When asked about the call for a two-state solution brought forward by Egyptian president Abdel Fattah al-Sissi, US president Donald Trump said his peace plan was about something very different – “rebuilding Gaza”.

Speaking to reporters on board Air Force One about the Gaza ceasefire deal, he said: “a lot of people like the one state solution a lot of people like the two state solution… I haven’t commented on that. At some point I’ll decide what I think is right, but I’d be in coordination with other states and other countries”.

Reporters also asked him abut the second phase of the deal for Gaza, and he responded saying: “You know, we have a lot of power”.

He added: “Those are you know really seriously rich countries and uh they can handle it,” he added, referring to the countries that had their leaders present in the summit.

title: Morning update
summary:
Morning update

Good morning Middle East Eye readers, here are the latest updates:

- US President Donald Trump commented on bringing up the subject of a pardon for Israeli prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu during his speech at the Israeli Knesset on Monday, saying he did so only because Netanyahu ‘was getting a very good hand [applause] and it was ‘good timing’.

- The list of Palestinians freed from Israeli prisons on Monday included the names of at least 55 health workers, including 24 nurses, seven doctors and two paramedics, according to advocacy organisation Healthcare Workers Watch.

- Brother of Al Jazeera correspondent Ibrahim al-Khalili, Mohammed, was among the Palestinians freed on Monday. He said during detention for 19 months, prisoners ‘were beaten and humiliated’.

- UN’s Relief Chief said Tom Fletcher says an additional $11m will be allocated from the UN’s emergency response fund to help ‘scale up aid’ in Gaza as winter months approach, bringing the total funds used to deliver ‘food, water, shelter and health services’ to $20m.

- Qatari Emir Sheikh Tamim bin Hamad Al Thani has praised the ‘positive outcomes of the Sharm el-Sheikh Peace Summit,' saying he hopes the deal ‘will serve as a starting point for future agreements that fulfil the aspirations of our brothers in the Gaza Strip’.

title: Sanders says humanitarian aid for Palestinians must be prioritised after 'widespread malnutrition and starvation'
summary:
Sanders says humanitarian aid for Palestinians must be prioritised after 'widespread malnutrition and starvation'

Vermont Senator Bernie Sanders said that the most important priority was to ensure that Palestinians in Gaza obtained humanitarian aid in the wake of the ceaefire deal in a social media post on X on Monday.

He urged the UN to have "unfettered access" amid "widespread malnutrition and starvation" in Gaza.

He also said the international community needed to help rebuild Gaza after "the entire infrastructure...had been destroyed," and advocated for Palestinians to "guide this process and determine their future".

Americans would have to grapple with "their role" in this "extremely dark chapter" he added.

He defended the right of Israelis to defend themselves after Hamas's attack, but not the right to "go to war against the entire Palestinian people".

title: Trump's Gaza victory lap: A Nobel prize, lots of money and 'a beautiful woman'
summary:
Trump's Gaza victory lap: A Nobel prize, lots of money and 'a beautiful woman'

US President Donald Trump’s Middle East visit had all the showmanship he relishes: an address at the Israeli Knesset, an escort of Egyptian fighter jets, and an impromptu nomination for the Nobel Prize by Pakistan’s prime minister.

“The war in Gaza is over…now the rebuilding begins,” Trump said on Monday when he touched down in the Egyptian Red Sea resort city of Sharm el-Sheikh - the second leg of a whirlwind Middle East tour that would usher in his Gaza peace deal.

Earlier in the day, Trump visited Israel. The US president used his time addressing the country’s parliament to reaffirm his commitment to the Gaza deal and advocate for the advancement of the Abraham Accords. He also lobbied Israel’s president to issue a pardon to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who faces a corruption trial.

Dozens of world leaders waited roughly three hours for Trump to arrive in Sharm el-Sheikh. Trump was greeted coming out of Air Force One by Egyptian President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, whose government fiercely resisted efforts to forcibly displace Palestinians to the Sinai Peninsula during Israel’s years-long offensive on the Gaza Strip.

You can read more here.

title: Trump says Hamas security forces deploying in Gaza with his 'approval'
summary:
Trump says Hamas security forces deploying in Gaza with his 'approval'

US President Donald Trump said he gave the "approval" for Hamas fighters to deploy throughout Gaza, in order to prevent a security vacuum.

Hours after the ceasefire went into effect on Friday, armed Hamas members could be seen moving freely in Khan Younis and other parts of the enclave.

Videos seen by Middle East Eye showed Palestinians cheering as they passed.

Speaking to reporters ahead of his trip to Israel and Egypt to mark his ceasefire agreement, the US president said that he believed Hamas wants "to stop the problems".

"And they've been open about it, and we gave them approval for a period of time," Trump said. "We are having them watch that there's not going to be big crime or some of the problems that you have when you have areas like this that have been literally demolished," he added.

You can read more here.

title: Netanyahu pulled out of Gaza summit after some leaders balk at him being there
summary:
Netanyahu pulled out of Gaza summit after some leaders balk at him being there

Israeli prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu was forced to pull out of the Gaza summit in Egypt on Monday after some leaders were unhappy at the prospect of having him there, AFP reported. 

Netanyahu was invited by US president Donald Trump to the summit in Sharm el-Sheikh at the last minute, but some leaders – such as Iraq’s Prime Minister Mohammed Shia al-Sudani – apparently said they would boycott the summit if he was there.

"The Iraqi delegation informed the Egyptian side that it was not prepared to participate in the regional summit if Netanyahu attended," adviser Ali al-Mousawi told AFP. 

“Iraq has taken a clear position on this matter and has informed the Egyptians of its rejection, and a number of other delegations have announced their intention to withdraw if Netanyahu participates,” he added.

He said Cairo had then informed Netanyahu he "could not be received, which led to the cancellation of his participation in the conference". 

Turkish media reported that Erdogan learned of Netanyahu's expected attendance while en route to Sharm el-Sheikh, and his plane circled over the Red Sea and refused to touch down until it was confirmed the Israeli leader would not be coming. 

Netanyahu said he would not be taking part "due to the timing", which coincided with the start at sundown of the Jewish holiday of Simhat Torah, his office said.

title: Trump's Gaza victory lap: A Nobel prize, lots of money and 'a beautiful woman'
summary:
Trump's Gaza victory lap: A Nobel prize, lots of money and 'a beautiful woman'

Submitted by Sean Mathews on Mon, 10/13/2025 - 21:23
Trump soaked up pageantry during Gaza Peace Summit, as Arab diplomats hope it is enough to keep him engaged on difficult details ahead
US President Donald Trump delivers a statement during a summit on Gaza in Sharm el-Sheikh, Egypt, on 13 October 2025 (Yoan Valast/Pool/AFP)
Off

US President Donald Trump’s Middle East visit had all the showmanship he relishes: an address at the Israeli Knesset, an escort of Egyptian fighter jets, and an impromptu nomination for the Nobel Prize by Pakistan’s prime minister.

“The war in Gaza is over…now the rebuilding begins,” Trump said on Monday when he touched down in the Egyptian Red Sea resort city of Sharm el-Sheikh - the second leg of a whirlwind Middle East tour that would usher in his Gaza peace deal.

Earlier in the day, Trump visited Israel. The US president used his time addressing the country’s parliament to reaffirm his commitment to the Gaza deal and advocate for the advancement of the Abraham Accords. He also lobbied Israel’s president to issue a pardon to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who faces a corruption trial.

Dozens of world leaders waited roughly three hours for Trump to arrive in Sharm el-Sheikh. Trump was greeted coming out of Air Force One by Egyptian President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, whose government fiercely resisted efforts to forcibly displace Palestinians to the Sinai Peninsula during Israel’s years-long offensive on the Gaza Strip.

In a sign of Sisi’s change of fortune, Trump showered praise on the leader and thanked him for using his ties to Hamas to help seal the ceasefire deal. Sisi, Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan and Qatari Emir Tamim bin Hamad al-Thani all signed documents recognising the ceasefire alongside Trump.

“This is a victory lap,” Merissa Khurma, a nonresident fellow at the Baker Institute, told Middle East Eye. “Does Trump deserve praise for bringing it home? Yes. But we all knew it really just needed pressure on Netanyahu.”

'A diplomatic trap'

The summit itself was almost tailor-made for Trump as the star. The event drew a diverse crowd ranging from Gulf leaders and European heads of state to the prime minister of Indonesia, and Gianni Infantino, the head of Fifa, football’s international governing body.

Trump soaked it up.

He delivered his speech with dozens of world leaders standing behind him and delighted in calling them out with a mix of flattery and taunts. He praised Gulf states, which he referred to as “some of the richest countries”, and applauded Viktor Orban, the prime minister of Hungary, and Erdogan. He called Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni “a beautiful, young woman”.

'Having so many leaders present is a positive sign for the potential to have the wide buy-in required for the ceasefire to hold'

- Jonathan Panikoff, Atlantic Council

At other times, he hissed at Norway and quietly criticised Spain, a laggard Nato spender. Trump also noted world leaders of countries that he said the US had stopped fighting. “That’s a little war that we stopped,” he said, pointing to the leaders of Armenia and Azerbaijan.

In an impromptu moment, Pakistani Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif took to the podium and publicly nominated Trump for the Nobel Peace Prize next year.

Behind the pageantry lurked a concern among Arab states that, having sealed the ceasefire, Trump might lose interest in the next phases. By letting Trump put his seal on the deal, one diplomat in the region familiar with the planning told MEE, Cairo and its partners hoped to keep Washington firmly linked to Gaza.

“It was a diplomatic trap to ensure Israel does not resume the war and to get Trump on board with that,” the official said.

The summit was remarkable in that no other flashpoint in the Israel-Palestine conflict has been internationalised in such a way, experts said.

“Having so many leaders present is a positive sign for the potential to have the wide buy-in that will be required for the ceasefire to hold and expand to a more durable peace,” Jonathan Panikoff, a former senior US intelligence official now at the Atlantic Council, told MEE.

'Start cleaning up'

Phase one of the ceasefire was practically complete by the time Trump arrived in Egypt, with Israeli troops withdrawing from central Gaza, though still occupying 58 percent of the enclave, and the last 20 living captives in Gaza released in exchange for Palestinian prisoners.

“Phase two has started as far as we’re concerned…You can start cleaning up," Trump said.

Analysts say that Trump was partly able to seal the ceasefire by focusing on Israel and Hamas’s initial acceptance of phase one, while leaving the hard questions of Hamas’s demilitarisation, Israel’s full withdrawal from Gaza and the enclave’s governance to a later day.

US and Arab officials told MEE that Arab, European and US officials are expected to start hashing out the details of an international force that will enter Gaza.

For now, Trump told reporters on Monday that the US had given its “approval” for Hamas security forces to deploy in Gaza to prevent crime.

“It’s not clear that the Gulf states are just going to pay for the reconstruction with a blank check'

- Merissa Khurma, Baker Institute

Trump did not use the term "Palestinians" in his address, although he did mention the "people of Gaza" and spent some time speaking with Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas.

“There is little reference in these speeches to the suffering of the Palestinian people. The death and destruction,” Khurma told MEE. “The Palestinians weren’t at the table to come up with Trump’s 20 points.”

Gaza has been reduced to rubble by two years of Israeli bombardment, and over 67,000 Palestinians have been killed in what has been recognised as a genocide by the United Nations.

In his speech, Trump promised that there is "going to be a lot of money coming into Gaza” and that he would publicly name the states that contributed to its reconstruction, including the dollar amount.

But Khurma said Trump’s expectation of Gulf money is not guaranteed. Qatar and the UAE have divergent views on the enclave’s governance, experts say, while Saudi Arabia is running steep budget deficits to pay for the economic vision plan of Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman.

“It’s not clear that the Gulf states are just going to pay for the reconstruction with a blank check,” she said.

Israel's genocide in Gaza

title: Eurovision organisers postpone vote on Israel's inclusion
summary:
Eurovision organisers postpone vote on Israel's inclusion

A vote on Israel’s participation in the Eurovision song contest next year has been postponed following a Gaza ceasefire deal, the organisers said on Monday.

A vote had been scheduled to take place in November after several countries pledged to boycott the event if Israeli contestants took part in the competition. The vote is to occur because of criticism of Israel and its war on Gaza, which has been recognised as a genocide by the United Nations. 

“The Board agreed to put the issue on the agenda of its ordinary Winter General Assembly, which will be taking place in December,” instead of the extraordinary meeting that had been slated to take place online in November, a European Broadcasting Union statement said.

title: Clinton congratulates Trump, Qatar and other world leaders on ceasefire
summary:
Clinton congratulates Trump, Qatar and other world leaders on ceasefire

In a post on X, former US President Bill Clinton congratulated Trump, Qatar and other world leaders on the ceasefire agreement on Monday. 

"President Trump and his administration, Qatar, and other regional actors deserve great credit for keeping everyone engaged until the agreement was reached."

However, Clinton stopped short of condemning Israel for waging a war that has been labelled a genocide by the United Nations, referring to it as a "conflict", failing to mention the more than 67,000 dead Palestinians. 

"The horrors of the October 7 attack on Israel and the conflict it reignited have resulted in unbearable human loss," he said.

title: The remains of four Israeli captives have been released and are in Israel
summary:
The remains of four Israeli captives have been released and are in Israel

The remains of four Israeli captives have now been released and have been transported to Israel, where they will be forensically examined and identified. 

Hamas released the remains of two more captives on Monday, in addition to two it released earlier in the day to the International Committee of the Red Cross.

US President Donald Trump said during his White House briefing last week that it would be challenging to locate all of the remains of the Israeli captives immediately because some of the bodies would be a little hard to find.

An international committee will help locate the bodies.
